title: R44430
content: The Office on Violence Against Women (OVW) administers programs under the Violence Against Women Act (VAWA) of 1994, providing financial and technical assistance to improve criminal justice responses to domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking. The Obama Administration's FY2017 request for OVW was $489 million, with proposed increases for grants related to domestic violence cases, civil legal assistance, violence on college campuses, and abuse prevention. The Obama Administration's FY2017 request for the Office on Violence Against Women (OVW) was $489 million, with proposed increases for grants related to domestic violence cases, civil legal assistance, violence on college campuses, and abuse prevention. Additionally, the request included increases for grants to combat violence on college campuses, abuse against the elderly, and tribal justice systems' response to domestic violence on tribal lands. New initiatives were proposed to reduce firearm lethality in domestic violence cases and enhance responses to campus sexual assault. Funding for the STOP Formula Grant program was proposed to be reduced by $15 million. The Obama Administration's FY2017 request for the Office on Violence Against Women (OVW) included funding for new initiatives to reduce firearm lethality in domestic violence cases and enhance responses to campus sexual assault. The proposed $5 billion 21st Century Justice Initiative aimed to invest $500 million annually for 10 years in criminal justice reform efforts. The program would focus on reducing crime, reversing practices leading to unnecessary incarceration, and building community trust through innovative approaches funded by the federal government. States could use the funding for objectives such as changing laws for shorter sentences, promoting community policing, and providing diversion and reentry services. 10% of the funding would be dedicated to reform efforts.
